plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A perennial bulbous plant native to Europe, characterized by its bright yellow trumpet-shaped flowers and long, slender leaves. It often signals the arrival of spring in temperate zones.
plants.location: Western Europe, especially the United Kingdom, France
plants.funFact: Wild daffodils can naturalize in woodlands and meadows, growing in large carpets of yellow in early spring.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub prized for its large, rose-like flowers. It blooms from late winter to spring with lush, glossy green leaves and flowers in various shades, including pink, red, and white.
plants.location: East Asia, widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellias are related to tea plants and have been cultivated in Asia for centuries for ornamental purposes.

plants.name: Acacia pycnantha
plants.description: Australiaâ€™s national floral emblem, this small tree produces vibrant yellow, fluffy flower clusters. It blooms in late winter to early spring and is adapted to dry climates.
plants.bloomingSeason: July to October in Australia (Southern Hemisphere). However, in some subtropical regions, cultivated plants may bloom sporadically around March.
plants.funFact: The golden wattleâ€™s flowering period varies geographically; while it naturally blooms in Southern Hemisphere winter to spring, some cultivated specimens in different climates may bloom off-season.

plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid magnolia notable for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that emerge before the leaves in early spring. Flowers range from white to pink and deep purple.
plants.location: Cultivated in temperate regions globally, originally from Asia
plants.funFact: Magnolia flowers have existed for millions of years, even before bees, and are pollinated by beetles.
